channel.description: Recent content in Character on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Welcome to the course on Character! In this course, I’ll give you all my tips on how to invent great characters for stories, but mostly how to write and develop them.

item.title: What is character?
item.description: To make sure we’re on the same page, this chapter gives my definition of character and a general overview of the theory for it.

item.title: Designing a Character
item.description: In general, all the tips in this course hold true for all characters of your story. But characters have different levels of importance.

item.title: Empathy
item.description: In earlier chapters, I already established a definition for empathy and why it’s the most important part of your characters to get right.

item.title: Flaws, Limitations & Handicaps
item.description: In earlier chapters, I described the idea of “audience interest”. A character only works if what they want is also interesting to the audience.

item.title: Purpose
item.description: We’ve discussed creating empathy for your characters and interest (through flaws). Now let’s move to the third component: linking your character to the plot by giving it a specific purpose.

item.title: Arcs & Growth
item.description: The chapters so far have mostly discussed character as a static point. The character is something. The character is a collection of traits, backstory, and restrictions.

item.title: Archetypes
item.description: Earlier, I mentioned how most people roughly fit into one or multiple stereotypes. A while ago, Karl Jung formalized these into 12 Archetypes.

item.title: The Five Questions
item.description: The approach below merely tells you to ask five questions of each character to really nail them down. These questions are designed to identify your main character’s arc.

item.title: The Self Contradiction
item.description: This is a very simple technique for improving characters. Every time I’ve written a story, every time I used it, I realized it was even more powerful than I thought.

item.title: The Interview System
item.description: Maybe you’ve been disappointed, so far, that this course only gives general advice. I give tips to quickly find a strong core for a character, and say that details (such as appearance or personality) flow from that.

item.title: The Casting Approach
item.description: So far, the advice I’ve given has been “character first”. You start by assembling a list of compelling characters, and let the plot come from their choices and interactions.

item.title: Purpose & Personality
item.description: We have learned tools for creating a story from character first. We have learned tools for creating a story from plot first.

item.title: The Three Sliders
item.description: As you get further into this course, you’ll notice characters are described more and more like a “list of properties”.

item.title: The Point System
item.description: Last chapter, we discussed the method of the three sliders. This was already a very “logical” or “numerical” approach to building characters.

item.title: Main Characters versus Side Characters
item.description: This chapter hopefully answers some questions about how to categorize characters, and how this helps simplify and streamline your cast of characters.

item.title: Basing on Real People
item.description: Many beginning writers get inspired by the real people around them, usually close to them, when designing characters. Is this good?

item.title: Fixing a Broken Story
item.description: If you’ve written your share of stories, you know the feeling. You started this story with a great idea, but now you’re just struggling.

item.title: Backstory
item.description: This chapter is the last one, because I hesitated on writing it. I’m an improviser, which means I invent backstory “as I go”.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: Congratulations! You’ve finished the course about Character (in Creative Writing). Hopefully I’ve given you tools for designing great characters that make your story come alive.
